page.title: 01Nanjizel Bay, St. Levan.
page.content: {Nanjizel}is an isolated and pictureque bay{two kilometres south of Land's {End.}The cliffs are of{granite}which {results in a 'castellated' appearance due to weathering of the joints in this rock. Each headland looks like a giant's tumbled pile of bricks as a result. West Penwith is part of an {igneous batholith}which outcrops on {Dartmoor, Bodmin Moor, Carnmenellis and the{Isles of Scilly.}Between these outcrops is metamorphic slate, called 'killas' by miners. Various{mineral {ores are found at the boundary of {these two rocks.}Nanjizel has typical granite cliff scenery, rugged yet less ominous in appearance than slate cliffs.{Low tide reveals many rock {pools filled with crabs, sea anenomes {and limpets.}A sandbar in the bay means that the cove gains or loses a beach as sand is washed in and out.
